sentences.sentence: Suddenly the Witch( 女巫 ) stepped boldly( 大胆地 ) out toward the Lion.
It was coming on, always singing, with a slow, heavy pace.
It was only twelve yards away.
She raised her arm and flung( 抛出 ) the iron bar straight at its head.
Nobody, least of all Jadis, could have missed at that range.
The bar struck the Lion fair between the eyes.
It glanced off( 击中后弹开 ) and fell with a thud( 砰的一声 ) in the grass. The Lion came on.
Its walk was neither slower nor faster than before; you could not tell whether it even knew it had been hit.
Though its soft pads( 爪垫 ) made no noise, you could feel the earth shake beneath their weight.
The Witch( 女巫 ) shrieked( 尖叫 ) and ran: in a few moments she was out of sight among the trees.
Uncle Andrew turned to do likewise( 同样地 ), tripped over a root, and fell flat on his face in a little brook( 小溪 ) that ran down to join the river.
The children could not move.
They were not even quite sure that they wanted to.
The Lion paid no attention to them. Its huge red mouth was open, but open in song not in a snarl( 咆哮 ).
It passed by them so close that they could have touched its mane( 鬃毛 ).
They were terribly afraid it would turn and look at them, yet in some queer( 奇怪的 ) way they wished it would.
But for all the notice it took of them they might just as well have been invisible( 看不见的 ) and unsmellable( 闻不到的 ).
When it had passed them and gone a few paces further it turned, passed them again, and continued its march eastward( 向东地 ).
Uncle Andrew, coughing and spluttering( 结结巴巴 ), picked himself up( 爬起来 ).
“Now, Digory,” he said, “we’ve got rid of that woman, and the brute( 野兽 ) of a lion is gone. Give me your hand and put on your ring at once.”
“Keep off,” said Digory, backing away from him. “Keep clear of him, Polly. Come over here beside me. Now I warn you, Uncle Andrew, don’t come one step nearer, we’ll just vanish( 消失 ).”
“Do what you’re told this minute, sir,” said Uncle Andrew. “You’re an extremely disobedient( 不听话的 ), ill-behaved little boy.”
“No fear,” said Digory. “We want to stay and see what happens. I thought you wanted to know about other worlds. Don’t you like it now you’re here?”
“Like it!” exclaimed( 惊呼 ) Uncle Andrew. “Just look at the state I’m in. And it was my best coat and waistcoat( 西服背心 ), too.”
He certainly was a dreadful( 糟透的 ) sight by now: for of course, the more dressed up you were to begin with,
the worse you look after you’ve crawled( 爬行 ) out of a smashed( 粉碎的 ) hansom( 双轮有篷马车 ) cab( 出租马车 ) and fallen into a muddy( 浑浊的 ) brook( 小溪 ).
“I’m not saying,” he added, “that this is not a most interesting place.
If I were a younger man, now—perhaps I could get some lively young fellow to come here first.
One of those big—game hunters.
Something might be made of this country.
The climate is delightful. I never felt such air.
I believe it would have done me good if—if circumstances( 环境 ) had been more favorable. If only we’d had a gun.”
“Guns be damned( 该死的 ),” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ). “I think I’ll go and see if I can give Strawberry a rub( 擦洗 ) down. That horse ’as more sense than some humans as I could mention.”
He walked back to Strawberry and began making the hissing( 发出嘶嘶声的 ) noises that grooms( 马夫 ) make.
“Do you still think that Lion could be killed by a gun?” asked Digory. “He didn’t mind the iron bar much.”
“With all her faults,” said Uncle Andrew, “that’s a plucky( 胆大包天的 ) gel( 姑娘 ), my boy. It was a spirited thing to do.”
He rubbed( 搓 ) his hands and cracked( 把...捏得劈啪作响 ) his knuckles( 指节 ),
as if he were once more forgetting how the Witch( 女巫 ) frightened him whenever she was really there.
“It was a wicked( 邪恶的 ) thing to do,” said Polly. “What harm had he done her?”
“Hullo! What’s that?” said Digory. He had darted( 飞奔 ) forward to examine something only a few yards away. “I say, Polly,” he called back. “Do come and look.”
Uncle Andrew came with her; not because he wanted to see but because he wanted to keep close to the children—there might be a chance of stealing their rings.
But when he saw what Digory was looking at, even he began to take an interest.
It was a perfect little model of a lamp-post, about three feet high but lengthening, and thickening in proportion( 比例 ),
as they watched it; in fact growing just as the trees had grown.
“It’s alive too—I mean, it’s lit,” said Digory.
And so it was; though of course, the brightness of the sun made the little flame in the lantern hard to see unless your shadow fell on it.
“Remarkable, most remarkable,” muttered( 嘀咕 ) Uncle Andrew.
“Even I never dreamed of Magic like this. We’re in a world where everything, even a lamp-post, comes to life and grows.
Now I wonder what sort of seed a lamp-post grows from?”
“Don’t you see?” said Digory. “This is where the bar fell—the bar she tore off the lamp-post at home.
It sank into the ground and now it’s coming up as a young lamp-post.”
(But not so very young now; it was as tall as Digory while he said this.)
“That’s it! Stupendous( 了不起的 ), stupendous( 了不起的 ),” said Uncle Andrew, rubbing( 搓 ) his hands harder than ever. “Ho, ho! They laughed at my Magic.
That fool of a sister of mine thinks I’m a lunatic( 疯子 ).
I wonder what they’ll say now? I have discovered a world where everything is bursting with life and growth.
Columbus, now, they talk about Columbus. But what was America to this?
The commercial( 商业的 ) possibilities of this country are unbounded( 无限的 ).
Bring a few old bits of scrap( 碎片 ) iron here, bury them, and up they come as brand( 崭新的 ) new railway( 铁路 ) engines( 火车头 ), battleships( 战列舰 ), anything you please.
They’ll cost nothing, and I can sell them at full prices in England.
I shall be a millionaire( 百万富翁 ). And then the climate! I feel years younger already. I can run it as a health resort( 疗养胜地 ).
A good sanatorium( 疗养院 ) here might be worth twenty thousand a year.
Of course I shall have to let a few people into the secret. The first thing is to get that brute( 野兽 ) shot.”
“You’re just like the Witch( 女巫 ),” said Polly. “All you think of is killing things.”
“And then as regards oneself,” Uncle Andrew continued, in a happy dream.
“There’s no knowing how long I might live if I settled here.
And that’s a big consideration when a fellow has turned sixty.
I shouldn’t be surprised if I never grew a day older in this country! Stupendous( 了不起的 )! The land of youth!”
“Oh!” cried Digory. “The land of youth! Do you think it really is?”
For of course he remembered what Aunt Letty had said to the lady who brought the grapes, and that sweet hope rushed back upon him.
“Uncle Andrew,” he said, “do you think there’s anything here that would cure Mother?”
“What are you talking about?” said Uncle Andrew. “This isn’t a chemist’s shop. But as I was saying—”
“You don’t care twopence( 一点儿 ) about her,” said Digory savagely( 猛烈抨击地 ). “I thought you might; after all, she’s your sister as well as my Mother.
Well, no matter. I’m jolly well( 当然 ) going to ask the Lion himself if he can help me.”
And he turned and walked briskly( 轻快地 ) away. Polly waited for a moment and then went after him.
“Here! Stop! Come back! The boy’s gone mad,” said Uncle Andrew.
He followed the children at a cautious( 谨慎的 ) distance behind;
for he didn’t want to get too far away from the green rings or too near the Lion.
In a few minutes Digory came to the edge of the wood and there he stopped.
The Lion was singing still. But now the song had once more changed.
It was more like what we should call a tune( 曲子 ), but it was also far wilder.
It made you want to run and jump and climb. It made you want to shout.
It made you want to rush at other people and either hug them or fight them.
It made Digory hot and red in the face.
It had some effect on Uncle Andrew, for Digory could hear him saying, “A spirited gel( 姑娘 ), sir.
It’s a pity about her temper( 脾气 ), but a dem fine woman all the same, a dem fine woman.”
But what the song did to the two humans was nothing compared with what it was doing to the country.

article_info.previous: 在“虚无”的世界里，天色渐渐变亮，Digory一行人终于看见了发出美妙歌声的生物，竟然是一头狮子。此时，狮子边歌唱边向他们走去，万物随着狮子的歌声而生长。

article_info.share_words: It made you want to run and jump and climb. It made you want to shoot. It made you want to rush at other people and either hug them or fight them.

question.cn: 女巫扔向狮子的铁棒击中了狮子吗？
question.en: Did the iron bar that the witch threw hit the Lion?

analysis: 文中提到：“The bar struck the Lion fair between the eyes. It glanced off and fell with a thud in the grass.”由此可知女巫扔向狮子的铁棒击中了狮子，但是狮子对此没有在意，因此选A。

question.cn: 谁被树根绊倒并摔在了河里？
question.en: Who tripped over a root and fell down into the river?

analysis: 文中提到：“Uncle Andrew turned to do likewise, tripped over a root, and fell flat on his face in a little brook that ran down to join the river.”由此可知，在逃跑的过程中被树根绊倒跌进水里的是Uncle Andrew，因此选C。

question.cn: 当Polly和Uncle Andrew来到Digory旁边，他们看见了什么？
question.en: When Polly and Uncle Andrew came to Digory’s side, what did they see?

analysis: 文中提到：“But when he saw what Digory was looking at, even he began to take an interest. It was a perfect little model of a lamp-post. . . ”由此得知，他们看见了一个小型灯柱，因此选A。

question.cn: 根据Digory的叙述，灯柱是从哪里来的？
question.en: According to Digory, where did this lamp-post come from?

options.en: It came from the real world.
It came from the magic world.

analysis: 文中提到：“This is where the bar fell- the bar she tore off the lamp-post at home. It sank into the ground and now it’s coming up as a young lamp-post.”由此可知，女巫从现实世界扭下来的铁棒掉进土里，这根铁棒长成了一个灯柱，因此选A。

question.cn: 为什么Uncle Andrew认为这个地方充满了商业潜力？
question.en: Why did Uncle Andrew think that this place was full of commercial possibilities?

options.cn: 因为他可以将这里的新鲜空气和树木卖往现实世界。
options.en: Because he could sell the fresh air and trees here to the real world.

options.cn: 因为他可以在这里埋下一些碎片然后收获完整的物件。
options.en: Because he could bury some scraps here and then harvest complete things.

options.cn: 因为他可以在这里埋下一些纸币然后收获数不清的钱。
options.en: Because he could bury some bank notes here and then harvest countless money.

analysis: 文中提到：“Bring a few old bits of scrap iron here, bury them, and up they come as brand new railway engines, battleships, anything you please. They’ll cost nothing, and I can sell them at full prices in England.”说明Uncle Andrew想着把物体的碎片埋在这里收获完整的物件再去卖掉，所以选B。
